resources.string: A confirmation has been sent to your email. To proceed with the deletion, please check your inbox and follow the instructions.
Select how accurately you\'d like to see the sensors\' live measurement values in the app. This setting doesn\'t affect history charts or alerts.
This page shows nearby Ruuvi sensors not yet added to the app. Tap a sensor to add it.
Alternatively, if your NFC is enabled, you can add a sensor using NFC by touching it with your phone.
Alert if sensor data hasn\'t been updated to the cloud for longer than %1$,d minutes.
Enter the desired delay to be used in minutes before alert is triggered. Minimum value is 2 minutes.
Movement alert is triggered if the value of the sensor\'s internal motion counter changes. This alert can be used, for example, to detect door movement or vibration in the vicinity of the sensor.
Sensor has been offline over %1$s minutes
Alert when less than %1$s or more than %2$s
You are running the latest firmware version, no need to update
User %1$s is already signed in. If you\'d like to use a different account, please sign out first and then try again.
This feature is available on devices with Android 8 and newer. Use the export to CSV option instead.
CO₂ is excellent, but PM2.5 is fair. You might want to improve air filtering.
CO₂ looks excellent and PM2.5 is good. A little fresher air would make it perfect.
CO₂ is great, but PM2.5 is poor. Consider air purifying or limiting particles indoors.
CO₂ is excellent, but PM2.5 levels are very high. The air needs filtering to be healthier.
Particles are excellent, but CO₂ is fair. Some ventilation would freshen things up.
Both CO₂ and PM2.5 are fair. Some ventilation and filtering could improve the air.
PM2.5 is good, but CO₂ is fair. Opening a window may help improve the balance.
CO₂ is fair and PM2.5 is poor. Fresh air and a purifier might help together.
CO₂ is fair, but PM2.5 is very high. The air would benefit from stronger cleaning.
CO₂ is good and particles are excellent. Air is fresh and healthy overall.
CO₂ is good, but PM2.5 is fair. The air could be a bit cleaner.
Both CO₂ and PM2.5 are good. A small improvement could make the air excellent.
CO₂ is good, but PM2.5 is poor. An air purifier might help balance things out.
CO₂ is good, but PM2.5 is very high. The air could benefit from cleaning or filtering.
It seems that your PM2.5 is excellent, but CO₂ is high. Ventilate the room for fresher air.
PM2.5 is fair and CO₂ is high. Ventilate the room, but be mindful of outside particle levels.
PM2.5 is good, but CO₂ is high. Some ventilation would improve the air.
Both CO₂ and PM2.5 are poor. Ventilation and air cleaning would help the air.
PM2.5 is very high and CO₂ is also high. The air needs both freshening and filtering.
CO₂ is very high, even though PM2.5 is excellent. Strong ventilation is needed.
PM2.5 is fair and CO₂ is very high. Ventilation is strongly recommended.
PM2.5 is good, but CO₂ is very high. Fresh air is needed to make the room healthier.
Both CO₂ and PM2.5 are poor, and CO₂ is very high. Air quality needs urgent improvement.
Both CO₂ and PM2.5 are very poor. The air is unhealthy—ventilate and purify as soon as possible.
Your air quality is excellent! Well done, enjoy the fresh air.
The air here is fantastic! Breathe easy and enjoy it.
Excellent air quality today—nothing to worry about.
Fresh and clean! Your air is in top shape.
You’ve got excellent air quality—just relax and enjoy.
The air feels great! Keep on enjoying this freshness.
Your air quality is fair. There are things to improve.
Your air quality is fair—there’s room to make it better.
Air’s okay, but it could be fresher. A little action helps.
Not bad, not great. Your air quality is in the middle zone.
The air is fair right now—worth improving if you can.
Air quality’s so-so. Some freshening up would help.
Your air quality is good! Maybe there is something you can do for it.
The air is good right now. A little tweak could make it even better.
You’ve got good air quality—nearly perfect!
Air’s looking good! Small improvements could make it excellent.
The air feels nice. Just a tiny step more and it’ll be excellent.
Good air quality today! With a bit of care, it can be even fresher.
Your air quality is poor. You should try to improve it.
Your air quality is poor—let’s work on improving it.
Hmm, the air isn’t great right now. A few changes could help.
Air quality is on the low side—you may want to refresh it.
Not the best air to breathe—time to improve things a bit.
Poor air quality at the moment. Let’s see how we can make it better.
Your air quality is very poor. You should try to improve it.
The air quality is very poor right now—try to improve it soon.
Careful, the air isn’t healthy. Some fresh air would help a lot.
Air quality is at its lowest—best to improve it quickly.
The air here really needs a refresh—let’s take care of it.
Very poor air quality detected. Please take steps to make it better.
You can disable background scanning in settings
Read more about Ruuvi account benefits or sign in later
Local sensor data can be downloaded, when you\'re within its Bluetooth range.

In normal use, it's not necessary to adjust the offset.

If you're an advanced user and you'd like to manually configure the factory calibrated sensors, it's possible to do so.

Calibration tips are available on ruuvi.com/support
Enter the expected humidity value from sensor under current conditions (%1$s):
Enter the expected pressure value from sensor under current conditions (%1$s):
Enter the expected temperature value from sensor under current conditions (%1$s):
In order to measure relative humidity as accurately as possible, a sodium chloride (salt) calibration is recommended. See video tutorials on how to easily do this at home.
Note that calibration data will be stored locally in your mobile device. After Ruuvi Station uninstall and install, you may need to recalibrate.
Select background image. If you\'re not signed in, you\'ll lose the image in case of app reinstall.
Charts feature works best with background scanning enabled.
Would you like to enable Bluetooth background scanning?

Do you own this sensor? If yes, please claim ownership of the sensor and it'll be added to your Ruuvi account. Each Ruuvi sensor can have only one owner. To claim ownership, you need to be signed in.

Benefits:

 ● Sensor names, background images, offsets and alert settings will be securely stored in the cloud

 ● Access sensors remotely over the Internet (requires a Ruuvi Gateway)

 ● Share sensors with friends and family (requires a Ruuvi Gateway)

 ● Browse up to 2 years of history on station.ruuvi.com (requires a Ruuvi Gateway)
Secure the ownership information of your sensors by claiming their ownerships in the app.
You are scanning the wrong Ruuvi sensor
Clear the local history data from the app?
Do you want to clear locally stored history data from the app? This won\'t clear internally stored history from the sensor or history data stored on the Ruuvi Cloud service.
In order to share the sensor, you need to have a Ruuvi Gateway router nearby the sensor
The entered one-time password (OTP) is wrong or expired

When the Disable Bluetooth option is activated, the app will disregard any measurements sent by Ruuvi sensors via Bluetooth when sensors are nearby a Ruuvi Gateway router. Instead, the app will exclusively receive the sensor measurement data from Ruuvi Cloud. For measurement data to be transmitted to Ruuvi Cloud, your sensor needs to be in the vicinity of a Ruuvi Gateway router.
Drag and drop the measurements into desired ordering.
Use dashboard view to see multiple sensors at a glance.
Seems that you don\'t have any Ruuvi sensors added yet.
You are not signed in.\n\nIf you have an account and have already added Ruuvi sensors to it, they will automatically synchronise with Ruuvi Station mobile app when you sign in.
Please enable location permission in Settings to include coordinates

This feature requires a location permission. In order to include your location coordinates, please select if you want precise or approximate location and allow access while using the app when prompted in the next dialog.
To be able to include location when the app is running in the background please allow the app to use your location \'all the time\' when prompted in the next dialog.
Also send location coordinates of this device

The accelerometer detects whether the device has moved or tilted. It measures changes along three directions (x, y, and z axes), which makes it possible to determine if the device is stationary or in motion.

Earth’s gravity causes about 1 g of acceleration on the axis pointing directly toward the ground.

If the values remain steady, the device is firmly in place. If the values change, the sensor detects that the device has moved, turned, or tilted. Sudden spikes in the readings indicate rapid movement, while slower changes suggest that the device has gradually tilted or shifted.

In fixed installations, stable acceleration values confirm that the sensor is securely positioned. In mobile or experimental setups, the values can be used for real-time monitoring of the device’s orientation or vibrations, for example.

Air quality is shown with a single index-like number that tells how good or bad the indoor air is. The score is based on two factors: particulate matter (PM2.5) floating in the air, and carbon dioxide (CO₂) that accumulates when people spend time indoors.

The air quality score takes both factors into account, but if either one rises too much, the overall value decreases. For example, if particle levels increase during cooking, the score will drop even if carbon dioxide is still at a good level.

The higher the score, the healthier the air is to breathe. Good indoor air supports alertness, concentration, and sleep quality. If the score falls below 70, it may be due to a temporary situation such as poor ventilation or cooking. If it drops below 40, it clearly indicates that fresh air is needed or that there is something indoors that is reducing air quality.

The easiest way to improve indoor air quality is to ventilate the room by opening windows. Using an air purifier can also help keep the score at a good level.

Optimal result: 90 – 100
Score scale: 0 – 100

Battery voltage indicates the condition of the sensor’s battery.

When the voltage starts to drop, the battery is running low. This can cause the sensor to measure less accurately or lead to gaps in the data. By monitoring the voltage, you can see in time when the battery needs replacing and avoid sudden device shutdowns.

A new coin cell battery typically starts at about 3 volts. When the value approaches 2.5 volts or lower, the battery is close to empty. If the reading suddenly drops below normal, it may be due to battery aging or cold temperatures reducing its efficiency.

Ruuvi Station shows a low battery warning when the voltage falls below a temperature-dependent threshold: 2.0 V at –20 °C, 2.3 V below 0 °C, and 2.5 V at other temperatures.

We recommend using CR2477 batteries from well-known manufacturers with RuuviTag sensors. The expected battery life under normal conditions is about 1–2 years. Rechargeable batteries are not suitable for use with Ruuvi sensors.

Battery voltage: 3V

Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is produced every time we breathe. If a room has poor ventilation, the level can rise quickly. This may cause tiredness, drowsiness, headaches, and reduced cognitive performance. Cooking, several people staying in the same space, or weak ventilation can also raise CO₂ levels.

Outdoor air normally contains about 420–430 ppm, while indoor levels above 1000 ppm indicate a need for ventilation. In bedrooms, it is best to stay well below this level to maintain good sleep quality.

To reduce CO₂ levels, set the alarm limit to 1000 so you know when it’s time to ventilate.

Optimal range: 400 – 500
Sensor measurement range: 350 – 40000

Absolute humidity indicates the amount of water vapor in grams per cubic meter of air (g/m³). Unlike relative humidity, it tells the actual amount of water vapor in the air.

Measuring absolute humidity is important in environments where temperature varies greatly and moisture control is critical. Accurate moisture readings benefit industries like manufacturing and storage by helping to prevent spoilage or degradation. At home, understanding actual moisture load helps determine when a humidifier, dehumidifier, or improved ventilation is needed.

Absolute humidity is most informative when viewed over time or alongside temperature and relative humidity. It helps identify conditions where air may feel dry despite moderate relative humidity — or the opposite.

Since comfort and air quality issues often relate more closely to the actual water content in the air than to percentage-based values, tracking this metric can reveal hidden indoor air balance trends that may be missed by relying solely on relative humidity.

The dew point is the temperature at which water vapor condenses (dew forms), and it is measured in °C, °F, or K.

Dew point temperature directly indicates the risk of condensation and significantly affects indoor comfort. A higher dew point means more moisture in the air, often leading to a humid or stuffy indoor environment. A low dew point indicates drier air.

Condensation on surfaces occurs when air cools to its dew point. This is a major concern for preventing mold growth, corrosion, and water damage in both residential and commercial spaces. If the temperature of a window or wall drops to or below the dew point, moisture condenses on the surface and may cause damage over time.

Dew point values change more slowly than relative humidity, making them a reliable indicator for identifying ventilation issues or sources of excess indoor moisture.

By monitoring the dew point together with absolute and relative humidity, you gain a more complete picture of humidity dynamics in real time. This helps protect your home's structure, furnishings, and electronics while improving indoor air quality.

Relative humidity (RH %) indicates how much moisture is in the air compared to the maximum amount the air can hold at a given temperature.

A balanced humidity level at home (ideally 30–50%) makes indoor air healthier. Too much humidity promotes mold and dust mites, while too little dries out the skin and respiratory system.

Humidity levels can vary between rooms and at different times of the day. Bathrooms and kitchens often show higher readings after showers or cooking. Place the sensor in the room you are most concerned about and track values over time to recognize recurring situations and take steps to avoid them.

You can manage humidity by adjusting indoor temperature and ventilating at times when outdoor humidity is lower than indoors. Once you learn to control indoor humidity, it is easier to maintain healthy air quality and also prevent potential moisture damage.

Relative humidity (%) is the most commonly used unit, but you can also choose absolute humidity or dew point in the app settings.

Optimal range: 40–80%
Sensor measurement range: 0–100%

For ideas on suitable alert limits, see Ruuvi’s use case examples: [link url="https://ruuvi.com/ideas/"]ruuvi.com/ideas[/link]
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

The movement counter displays movements detected via changes in the accelerometer.

Monitoring the device’s motion activity indicates whether it has been moved or if its surroundings have been disturbed.

Note that more events than expected may be recorded in unstable placements, such as on window sills.

The NOx index indicates how much nitrogen oxides are in the air.

These are harmful gases produced, for example, by traffic exhaust, gas stoves, fireplaces, or some heating devices. Even small amounts can irritate the respiratory tract, worsen asthma, and increase susceptibility to infections. Long-term exposure can also affect the lungs and heart.

The NOx index does not provide exact concentrations but shows a trend: whether air quality has improved or worsened compared to before. For example, during cooking or when outdoor pollution increases, the value can rise quickly.

The sensor works best when it is not placed directly next to stoves or ventilation outlets.

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a 24-hour average of 25 µg/m³ for nitrogen dioxide (NO₂).

Sensor measurement range: 0 – 500

Particulate matter (PM) refers to tiny, invisible particles in the air, such as dust, pollen, smoke, and other pollutants. Very small particles (PM2.5 and smaller) are harmful to health because they can reach deep into the lungs and worsen allergies and respiratory symptoms.

By monitoring PM levels, you can detect when indoor air quality decreases, for example due to cooking, vacuuming, burning candles, or outdoor traffic pollution. This helps you react in time by ventilating or using an air purifier.

Place the sensor where it is not directly next to emission sources, such as a stove, to keep the readings reliable. It is best to interpret the measurements as trends – noticing when the values rise or fall – rather than focusing on single numbers.

The sensor provides an estimate of the amount of particles in the air. The most commonly monitored value is PM2.5. In the settings, you can also choose to display other particle sizes, such as PM1.0, PM4.0, and PM10.

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a daily average PM2.5 level of 15 μg/m³. This guideline applies to outdoor air but also serves as a benchmark for improving indoor air quality.

Sensor measurement range: 0 – 1000

Barometric pressure (Pa, hPa, mmHg, inHg) indicates the pressure exerted by the weight of air at a specific location — essentially, how much the atmosphere is pressing down on the Earth's surface at that moment.

Monitoring air pressure helps anticipate weather changes and understand ventilation dynamics, which can affect building integrity and indoor comfort.

To ensure the best accuracy, do not place the sensor directly in airflow, such as near fans, ventilation vents, or open windows, as these can temporarily affect the readings.

The altitude of the measurement location above sea level influences the pressure value and, consequently, the measurement results. Air pressure at sea level is 1013.25 hectopascals (hPa).

Sensor measurement range: 500–1155 hPa

Signal strength (RSSI) indicates the quality of the Bluetooth connection. The stronger the signal (closer to 0 dBm), the more reliably sensor data is updated on the receiving device. If the signal is weak, the connection may drop or be lost entirely, causing measurement data to stop updating.

Connection quality can be affected by the distance between the sensor and the receiving device, walls and other obstacles, as well as interference from household electronics.

Monitoring signal strength helps you place the sensor in an optimal location. If the signal is weak, you can improve the connection by moving the sensor so it has a clearer line of sight to the receiving device. This ensures measurement data is shown reliably in the app.

Optimal result: -60 – 0
Sensor measurement range: -100 – 0
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

The temperature sensor measures the ambient air temperature.

At home, temperature significantly affects comfort, sleep quality, concentration, and overall health. Monitoring temperature also helps optimize energy costs and improve living comfort.

Indoors, place the sensor at eye level, away from surfaces or objects that conduct heat or cold, and from drafty areas.

Ideally, install the sensor upright so that air can flow freely around it. For outdoor use (RuuviTag/RuuviTag Pro), place the sensor in the shade and protect it from direct rain.

Note: Although the sensor detects and reports temperature changes very quickly, it may take up to an hour to fully reach thermal equilibrium with the surrounding environment. This is normal device behavior.

For ideas on suitable alert limits, see Ruuvi’s use case examples: [link url="https://ruuvi.com/ideas/"]ruuvi.com/ideas[/link]

The temperature sensor measures the ambient air temperature.

At home, temperature significantly affects comfort, sleep quality, concentration, and overall health. Monitoring temperature also helps optimize energy costs and improve living comfort.

Indoors, place the sensor at eye level, away from surfaces or objects that conduct heat or cold, and from drafty areas.

Ideally, install the sensor upright so that air can flow freely around it. For outdoor use (RuuviTag/RuuviTag Pro), place the sensor in the shade and protect it from direct rain.

Note: Although the sensor detects and reports temperature changes very quickly, it may take up to an hour to fully reach thermal equilibrium with the surrounding environment. This is normal device behavior.

For ideas on suitable alert limits, see Ruuvi’s use case examples: [link url="https://ruuvi.com/ideas/"]ruuvi.com/ideas[/link]

The temperature sensor measures the ambient air temperature.

At home, temperature significantly affects comfort, sleep quality, concentration, and overall health. Monitoring temperature also helps optimize energy costs and improve living comfort.

Indoors, place the sensor at eye level, away from surfaces or objects that conduct heat or cold, and from drafty areas.

Ideally, install the sensor upright so that air can flow freely around it. For outdoor use (RuuviTag/RuuviTag Pro), place the sensor in the shade and protect it from direct rain.

Note: Although the sensor detects and reports temperature changes very quickly, it may take up to an hour to fully reach thermal equilibrium with the surrounding environment. This is normal device behavior.

For ideas on suitable alert limits, see Ruuvi’s use case examples: [link url="https://ruuvi.com/ideas/"]ruuvi.com/ideas[/link]

The VOC index gives a single number showing how much volatile chemicals are in the air.

The index mimics the human sense of smell by indicating the relative intensity of odors and also detects odorless VOCs, though it cannot distinguish between them.

These chemicals can be released from many everyday products, such as cleaning agents, paints, furniture, and even some common household appliances. When VOC levels are too high, they may cause eye, nose, or throat irritation, headaches, and long-term health risks.

VOC values can vary throughout the day. For example, cleaning, painting, or bringing in new furniture can cause levels to rise quickly.

The best approach is to monitor measurements over several days and take note of activities at home when values change. This helps identify where pollutants are coming from.

If VOC levels rise, ventilate the room, use an air purifier, or choose products with fewer chemicals. This helps keep indoor air healthy.

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a maximum indoor level of 0.05 mg/m³ (or 0.05 ppm) for total volatile organic compounds (TVOCs).

Sensor measurement range: 0 – 500

[title]Device Update[/title]

1. Bring your mobile device close to your Ruuvi sensor

2. Tap the Start the update button and wait for the process to complete

3. When the firmware update is finished, the device will reboot to complete the update.
Sensor\'s battery voltage seems to be low and the firmware update process may fail. We recommend to replace the battery before updating.
Unable to get latest firmware. Check your Internet connection.
Do not close the app or power off the sensor during the update.
Downloading the latest firmware to be updated...
No data available \nin the selected history window.

Date,Temperature (%1$s),Humidity (%2$s),Pressure (%3$s),RSSI (dBm),Acceleration X (g),Acceleration Y (g),Acceleration Z (g),Voltage (V),Movement counter (movements),Measurement sequence number,TX power (dBm)
This sensor has been claimed by another user. You can force the ownership to your account if you have physical access to this sensor. Each Ruuvi sensor can have only one owner.

Force claim is done by using Near-Field Communication (NFC). Make sure NFC is enabled on your mobile device.

	1. Touch your Ruuvi sensor with your mobile device to start the claiming process.

	2. When successfully claimed, you will be sent back to sensor settings.

If claiming was unsuccessful or NFC is not available on your device:

	1. Open the cover of your Ruuvi sensor.

	2. Locate the round black button (or button "B" in case your sensor has 2 buttons) on the white circuit board and press it briefly to start the claiming process.

	3. When successfully claimed you will be sent back to sensor settings.
Nope, it did not work. Is the URL correct?
Nope, it did not work. Response code: %1$d

Bluetooth history download failed. Check that you\'re within Bluetooth range, your sensor has firmware that supports downloading and that the sensor is not simultaneously connected to another iOS device. Sensor connection is reserved for Ruuvi Station when using connected mode in iOS.
Sometimes the history download is slow due to the Bluetooth connectivity. Please wait a moment.

Ruuvi Station downloads the internal history of the sensor for the last 10 days if the measurement history is available.\n\nThe history is downloaded using a Bluetooth connection. Make sure you are near the sensor.
Ruuvi Station is an easy-to-use application that allows you to monitor the measurement data of Ruuvi sensors.

Ruuvi's website: ruuvi.com
Ruuvi Forum: f.ruuvi.com
Ruuvi blog: ruuvi.com/blog
Ruuvi on Twitter: twitter.com/ruuvicom
Just like Ruuvi sensors, Ruuvi Station apps are open source. Follow the development and contribute at: github.com/ruuvi
Get started using the Ruuvi Station mobile application with our online guides: ruuvi.com/support/station-mobile
By using the application, you accept Ruuvi\'s standard terms and conditions: ruuvi.com/terms
Find help using the Ruuvi Station apps, Ruuvi products and Ruuvi Cloud service from our support center: ruuvi.com/support
Air quality index is based on two factors: particulate matter (PM2.5) floating in the air, and carbon dioxide (CO₂) that accumulates when people spend time indoors
To enjoy all the features, create a free account or sign in to your existing Ruuvi account by entering your email address.

Ruuvi Station mobile app supports maximum 10 days of history. Ruuvi Cloud subscribers are able to view up to 3 years of historical data using web app at ruuvi.com/station (requires Ruuvi Gateway router).
Contact support@ruuvi.com if you wish to change the email address associated with this user account.
Only sensors within range of your Ruuvi Gateway can be shared.
Synchronisation failed: need to log in first

A free account will be created for this email if you don\'t already have one. Only email address is required. We keep your information safe.

In order to scan nearby Bluetooth devices in the background, Android requires background location access to be enabled. 

Please click 'allow all the time' on next permission dialog if you'd like to use the background scanning feature. 
\We do not collect or store your location data.

Ruuvi Station requires location permission to detect and communicate with nearby Bluetooth devices, even when the app is closed or not in use.

We do not collect or store your location data.

This permission is required by Android for Bluetooth scanning on devices running Android 11 or older.

To scan nearby Bluetooth devices, please grant permission to find and connect to nearby devices. This permission is also required for background scanning if enabled in the app settings, even when the app is closed.\n\nRuuvi Station does not use this information to collect or store your location data.
Please enable location permission in settings to see sensors.
Please allow to show nearby devices in settings to see sensors.
No history to show. No measurements received in this period. Load sensor memory by pressing sync in the history view.

[title]Prepare your sensor[/title]

1. Open the cover of your Ruuvi sensor

2. Locate the small round black buttons on the white circuit board; older Ruuvi sensors have 2 buttons labelled “R” and “B” while newer ones have only one button without a label.

3. Set the sensor to updating mode:

3.1. If your sensor has 2 buttons: keep “B” button pressed while tapping button “R” momentarily. Release button “B”.

3.2. If your sensor has a single button: keep the button pressed for 10 seconds.

4. If set successfully, you will see a solid red light lit on the circuit board and the button in the app will change to “Start the update”.
1. Open the cover of your Ruuvi sensor
2. Locate the small round black buttons on the white circuit board; older Ruuvi sensors have 2 buttons labelled “R” and “B” while newer ones have only one button without a label.
3. Set the sensor to updating mode:
3.1. If your sensor has 2 buttons: keep “B” button pressed while tapping button “R” momentarily. Release button “B”.
3.2. If your sensor has a single button: keep the button pressed for 10 seconds.
4. If set successfully, you will see a solid red light lit on the circuit board and the button in the app will change to “Start the update”.
No sensors added\nPress here to add sensors
By removing the sensor, your sensor ownership status will be revoked. After removal, someone else can claim ownership of the sensor. Each Ruuvi sensor can have only one owner.

By removing the sensor, your sensor ownership status will be revoked and sensor settings, such as name, background image, calibration settings and alert settings will be removed. After removal, someone else can claim ownership of the sensor. Each Ruuvi sensor can have only one owner.
I also want to remove sensor history data from Ruuvi Cloud.
Do you want to remove the sensor? You can add it again later, if needed.

If you choose to remove this sensor, it will result in the deletion of your locally stored measurement history, along with the removal of any related sensor settings like name, background image, calibration, and alert configurations.\n\nYou can add this sensor later again, if needed.
If you remove the sensor, the owner of the sensor will be notified and you will not be able to access the sensor anymore.

If you choose to remove this shared sensor, the owner of the sensor will be notified and you will not be able to access the sensor anymore.\n\nYou will also lose any related sensor settings like name, background image and alert configurations.
Your sensors are displayed in alphabetical order.
Are you certain you wish to revert the sensor card ordering to alphabetical sorting?

Notice that data sent by Ruuvi sensors can be received using mobile devices or Ruuvi Gateway routers. The received signal strength will be different depending on the receiving device and it will affect the value being used to trigger RSSI alert. Use Disable Bluetooth -mode when you want to record signal strength data only via Ruuvi Gateway.
Signing in to the app has many advantages. Settings will be safely stored to your account:
Trigger Bluetooth alert notification only once per hour even if alert was retriggered.
If you experience any issues with background scanning you should disable battery optimisation for Ruuvi Station. This procedure may vary depending on your device vendor, model and Android version.
Go to Android Settings -> Apps -> Ruuvi Station -> Battery -> Battery Optimisation and select \'Don\'t optimise for Ruuvi Station\'.

On Huawei devices go to Android Settings -> Apps -> Ruuvi Station -> Power usage details -> App launch. Disable \'Manage Automatically\' and enable options: \'Auto-Launch\', \'Secondary Launch\' and \'Run in background\'.
On Samsung devices go to Android Settings -> Battery -> App power saving detail and set option \'Turned off\' for Ruuvi Station.

On Samsung devices go to Android Settings -> Device Maintenance (or Device Care) -> Battery. Disable \'Put unused apps to sleep\'. Disable \'Auto-disable unused apps\'. Remove Ruuvi Station from the list of sleeping apps. Disable background restrictions for Ruuvi Station.
On Xiaomi devices go to Android Settings -> Apps -> Manage apps -> Ruuvi Station. Enable Autostart and set Battery Saver to \'No restrictions\'.
Continuous background scanning mode is enabled.\nData logging interval: %1$s
No background scanning mode is enabled
This feature enables background scanning, meaning that your phone will periodically search for beacons, even when you are not using it.
The app will periodically search for beacons using a service (with notifications), allowing for very frequent and reliable scanning, even when you are not using it.
Define how often the background scanning will run
Charts may be updated slowly when enabled.
Configure interval between points shown on chart
Small dots will help to understand when measurements were collected.
Set interval between points for chart from 1 to 60 minutes. Smaller values mean a more accurate chart, but also a higher performance requirement for your device.
Configure the period of history to be shown on chart from 1 to 10 days.
If you are using Ruuvi Cloud and Ruuvi Gateway, you will be able to receive email alerts by enabling this.
When you add a URL here, the app will execute an HTTP POST with the linked sensors when it does background scanning. \n\nFor more info, check the documentation.
Choose the humidity unit you want to be displayed.
Choose the pressure unit you want to be displayed.

Shared successfully! This email address isn\'t linked to a Ruuvi account yet. An invite to create a free account has been sent. Once created, you\'ll see it in the sharee listing.
You have used %1$,d/%2$,d of maximum shares of this sensor. The sensor has been shared to following users:

You can share the sensor with friends and family if it's in range of a Ruuvi Gateway.

Receiver will be notified by email. If the receiver doesn't have a Ruuvi account, a free Ruuvi account will automatically be created at first log in.

Note that the sensor's custom name and background image will be shared. The name and image sync is one time only, and after this, they can be privately customised by the receiver. Offset values (if any) set by the owner, will be automatically synced, and the receiver will always see the final corrected values.
Do you want to unshare sensor for %1$s?

Benefits:

 ● Sensor names, background images, offsets and alert settings will be securely stored in the cloud

 ● Access sensors remotely over the Internet (requires a Ruuvi Gateway)

 ● Share sensors with friends and family (requires a Ruuvi Gateway)

 ● Browse up to 2 years of history on station.ruuvi.com (requires a Ruuvi Gateway)

Sign in or create a free Ruuvi account
Are you sure you want to skip sign in?

When you sign out, sensors the ownerships of which you\'ve claimed on the sensor settings page will be automatically removed from the app. When you sign in again using the same email address, the sensors will be returned from the cloud.\n\nDo you want to sign out?

This is a completely free app that does not support monthly subscription purchases or other in-app purchases. If you are a user of the Ruuvi Gateway router and you are looking for more detailed information about your Ruuvi account, go to our website and sign in.

Ownership of this sensor has been claimed to your Ruuvi account. Press Unclaim to remove this sensor\'s settings and related data from your Ruuvi account.

To apply changes simply sync data from dashboard or wait till next sync.
Here, you can choose which measurements you\'d like to see and in what order. Switch the "Use default" toggle off to customise the settings.
Swipe to see what Ruuvi Station can do for you.
Measure environmental data: temperature, relative humidity and air pressure.

Press SCAN to find and add nearby sensors to your Ruuvi Station.
Add sensors to app before using widgets
To allow Ruuvi widgets to refresh automatically, please disable the app\'s battery optimisation.

Enable background scanning to update local sensor values via Bluetooth in the widget. This isn\'t needed for cloud sensors with Ruuvi Gateway. Background scanning interval can be set in Ruuvi Station app settings (currently set to %1$s).
You can use Ruuvi widgets if your sensors are in range of a Ruuvi Gateway or if someone has shared with you a Ruuvi sensor.
Cannot see all your sensors in the list? Make sure that you\'ve claimed ownership of all your sensors and that the sensors are in the range of a Ruuvi Gateway router.
Select the type of sensor to display in the widget
Please sign in first. To make use of widgets, you need a Ruuvi Gateway router.
